question.text: In accordance with the study of industrial melanism in England, which of these is NOT correct?

options.text: Before industrialization, light-winged moths were more on trees than dark-winged moths.
Dark winged or melanic moths were a mutant variety.
After industrialization, melanic moths reduced number.
Lichens could grow over tree trunk in a non-polluted atmosphere.

solution.text: Industrial melanism is a classic example of natural selection. It was seen in England that moth (Biston betularia) were available in two varieties. Black and White in colour. In earlier times the white moth were able to survive as these used to camouflage on the barks while black moth were spotted easily. In 1950 industrilisation began in England. This resulted in release of soot and this was deposited on the barks of trees. Thus the barks of trees became black and thus black or dark moths were favoured and survived white white moths were easily spotted by predators. These black moths are also known as melanic moths.
